docs.lead_paragraph: Little fingers can seed tomatoes and pick herbs off stems, but children may not like to eat the vegetables they just prepared.
docs.abstract: Elaine Louie Sprouts column notes that children don’t necessarily like to eat vegetables and their parents, especially if they are chefs, appreciate not just the healthfulness of vegetables but also their extraordinary range of flavors and possibilities; suggests that parents don’t try to sneak in the vegetables, instead, make simple tasty dishes that showcase the produce.
docs.snippet: Little fingers can seed tomatoes and pick herbs off stems, but children may not like to eat the vegetables they just prepared....

headline.seo: Chefs, Restaurateurs and Cookbook Authors Cook Vegetables With Their Children

docs.lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (Showtime) COACH CARTER (2005). Samuel L. Jackson stars in this tough-love sports melodrama based on the true story of Ken Carter, a high school basketball coach who benched his undefeated but underfinanced team in Richmond, Calif., until they showed academic improvement. Robert Ri’chard is Damien Carter, the coach’s son, who transferred from a prosperous parochial school — and basketball powerhouse — to play for his father.

docs.lead_paragraph: Philadelphia quarterback Donovan McNabb, who is recovering from sports hernia surgery that ended his season prematurely, says he thinks he has more than just his injury to rehabilitate. He says he believes the Eagles' locker room could use some healing, too. The Eagles, who finished 6-10 after reaching the Super Bowl a year ago, were torn apart by the Terrell Owens soap opera that erupted during the season. Owens, who repeatedly expressed his dissatisfaction with McNabb, was eventually deactivated. His agent, Drew Rosenhaus, has been given permission to seek a trade, and Owens met with Denver Coach Mike Shanahan on Monday.
docs.abstract: Philadelphia Eagles quarterback Donovan McNabb discusses tumultuous season (M)

headline.main: Recovering McNabb Says the Eagles Need Healing

docs.lead_paragraph: A man who was installing an M.R.I. machine at New York-Presbyterian Hospital was killed yesterday, apparently after nitrogen he was using leaked from its tank, officials said. Six other people were injured in the incident. The worker, Paul Ambrose, 25, of England, died about 11:25 a.m., apparently from asphyxiation, while working in a poorly ventilated trailer alongside the hospital on 70th Street and York Avenue, said Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who arrived at the hospital shortly after the incident occurred.

docs.lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (2) VICTORY IS YOUR DUTY In the past seven Olympic Games, Cuba has dominated boxing, earning 32 medals, 26 of them gold. But Fidel Castro’s faltering health has thrown the future of the sport — viewed not merely as an athletic activity but also a display of revolutionary fervor — into question there. This “Wide Angle” documentary ventures for the first time into the Havana Boxing Academy, the institution that grooms boys, starting at 9, for stardom in the ring, where the fight is not just for Cuba, but for Castro, too. (Christian Martínez, left, and his coach, Yosvani Borachea, are pictured above.).
